div.head: Summary
div.p: The Twelve Buddhas opens at Rājagṛha with a dialogue between the Buddha Śākyamuni and the bodhisattva Maitreya about the eastern buddhafield of the buddha King of Jewels. Śākyamuni prophesies that when this buddha passes into complete nirvāṇa, the bodhisattva Incomparable will take his place as the buddha Victory Banner King. Śākyamuni then provides the names of the remaining ten tathāgatas, locating them in the ten directions surrounding Victory Banner King’s buddhafield Full of Pearls. After listing the full set of names of these twelve buddhas and their directional relationship to Victory Banner King, the Buddha Śākyamuni provides an accompanying mantra-dhāraṇī and closes with a set of thirty-seven verses outlining the benefits of bearing the names of these buddhas in mind.

div.head: Acknowledgements
div.p: Translated by the Dharmachakra Translation Committee under the supervision of Chökyi Nyima Rinpoche. The translation was produced by Adam Krug and then checked against the Tibetan and edited by Ryan Damron.

The Twelve Buddhas opens in Rājagṛha, where the Buddha Śākyamuni is accompanied by a large gathering of monks and bodhisattvas. The Buddha begins with a description of the eastern buddhafield Full of Pearls, where the buddha King of Jewels resides and teaches the Dharma. After describing King of Jewels to Maitreya and the assembly, Śākyamuni asks who among them is willing to renounce cyclic existence and take up his banner once King of Jewels has passed into parinirvāṇa and his teachings have faded from the world. He then issues a prophecy that the bodhisattva Incomparable will take up the banner of King of Jewels, earning him the name Victory Banner King. The text then names the buddhas who will populate the buddhafields surrounding Victory Banner King. This description reveals the following set of twelve buddhas and their coordinates within a directional maṇḍala:

item.p: 3. Stainless Light of the Entire Array (east)
5. Renowned Victor Crowned with a Clear Moon (west)

div.p: No location for King of Jewels is given in the text, but it might be assumed that this buddha should be visualized directly above his successor, Victory Banner King. The theme of royal coronation provides the underlying structure for the directional maṇḍala of the twelve buddhas, with both buddhas located in the center identified as kings and the buddhas who surround them in the ten directions each expressing their respect for Victory Banner King as the successor to King of Jewels. This section of the text concludes with a description of the benefits that accrue from reciting the names of the twelve buddhas. The liturgy then progresses to a mantra-dhāraṇī recitation practice before ending with a set of thirty-seven verses describing the benefits of bearing the names of the twelve buddhas in mind.

The catalogue of the Peking Imperial Palace collection contains two Sanskrit witnesses to the text, Peking Imperial Palace, STP 6.1416, 6.1420. but these sources were unfortunately not available to be consulted for this translation. A complete list of all the Sanskrit, Chinese, and Tibetan sources for The Twelve Buddhas can be accessed at The Buddhist Canons Research Database: http://databases.aibs.columbia.edu/index.php. The first Chinese translation of this text was completed by Jñānagupta in 587 ce (T. 1348) 闍那崛多 Shénàjuéduō. For more information on this figure, see Lewis R. Lancaster, “K 301,” The Korean Buddhist Canon, accessed November 16, 2018, http://www.acmuller.net/descriptive_catalogue/files/k0301.html. and the second was produced by I-ching in 711 ce (T.1349). 義淨 Yijing. For more information on this figure, see Lewis R. Lancaster, “K 302,” The Korean Buddhist Canon, accessed November 16, 2018, http://www.acmuller.net/descriptive_catalogue/files/k0302.html. The translator’s colophon to the Tibetan translation tells us that The Twelve Buddhas was translated by the Indian paṇḍitas Jinamitra and Dānaśīla along with the Tibetan translator Yeshé Dé (c. eighth century). The text is listed as a sūtra in both the Denkarma Yoshimura (1950), 137. and Phangthangma dkar chag ’phang thang ma (2003), 17. royal Tibetan catalogues of translated works, which tells us that the Tibetan translation was completed prior to the compilation and publication of the Denkarma catalogue in 812 ce.

This translation was completed in consultation with the versions of the text from the General Sūtra Section (mdo sde),This text, Toh 853, and all those contained in this same volume (gzungs ’dus, e), are listed as being located in volume 100 of the Degé Kangyur by the Buddhist Digital Resource Center (BDRC). However, several other Kangyur databases—including the eKangyur that supplies the digital input version displayed by 84000 reading room—list this work as being located in volume 101. This discrepancy is partly due to the fact that the two volumes of the gzungs ’dus section are an added supplement not mentioned in the original catalogue, and also hinges on the fact that the compilers of the Tōhoku catalogue placed another text—which forms a whole, very large volume—the Vimala­prabhā­nāma­kālacakra­tantra­ṭīkā (dus ’khor ’grel bshad dri med ’od, Toh 845), before the volume 100 of the Degé Kangyur, numbering it as vol. 100, although it is almost certainly intended to come right at the end of the Degé Kangyur texts as volume 102; indeed its final fifth chapter is often carried over and wrapped in the same volume as the Kangyur dkar chags (catalogue). Please note this discrepancy when using the eKangyur viewer in this translation. the Tantra Collection (rgyud ’bum), and the Compendium of Incantations (gzungs ’dus) of the Degé Kangyur in conjunction with the text as it appears in the Stok palace Kangyur and the Comparative Edition (dpe bsdur ma). The only notable variant between these versions of the text is that the witnesses in the General Sūtra Section of the Degé and in the Stok Kangyur refer to the bodhisattva prophesied to become the next buddha presiding over the buddhafield Full of Pearls by the name Stainless (dri med) instead of the more common name Incomparable (’dra ba med). D 273 and S refer to this bodhisattva by the name Stainless (dri med) instead of Incomparable (’dra ba med). This translation uses the name Incomparable (’dra ba med) because this is also the name for this bodhisattva as it appears in versions of this text from the Yongle, Lithang, Kangxi, Narthang, and Choné Kangyurs. The dhāraṇī in this text is rendered in Sanskrit transliteration based on the Degé, with significant variants noted.The correlating section from the eKangyur (based on the Degé) may be viewed by clicking on the folio references, which will be displayed according to the Toh number selected from the 84000 reading room: D 273, D 511, or D 853. A tentative English translation of the dhāraṇī is also provided in a note.

div.head: The Translation
The Noble Mahāyāna Sūtra “The Twelve Buddhas”

div.p: Homage to all buddhas and bodhisattvas.

Thus did I hear at one time. The Blessed One was residing on Vulture Peak at Rājagṛha with a great saṅgha of one thousand two hundred and fifty monks and a great saṅgha of twelve thousand bodhisattvas that included the bodhisattva Ajita and others. The Blessed One addressed the bodhisattva great being Maitreya, saying, “Maitreya, to the east of this buddhafield, past as many buddhafields as there are grains of dust in ten inexpressible billions of buddhafields, there is a world system called Full of Pearls. In that buddhafield there is a tathāgata, arhat, completely perfect buddha named King of Jewels. The brilliant light of his good qualities is as beautiful as a glorious pure sky free from dust. His body is like a lotus flower, lovely as a resplendent blue beryl gemstone. He is worshiped with the most supreme and excellent perfumes. His body is elegantly adorned in manifold ways. He radiates immeasurable sunrays from the top of his beautiful crown ornament. He is ornamented with an aspiration like radiant moonbeams. He is a supreme emanation, devoid of desire, whose vast array manifests out of the expanse of phenomena. He nurtures and teaches the Dharma to the beings who live there. Who among you will bear the banner of that victorious one? Who will renounce cyclic existence for a great eon that consists of eons equal to the number of grains of dust in Jambudvīpa?”
Then the Buddha issued the following prophecy about the bodhisattva great being Incomparable: ’dra ba med] D 511, D 853; dri med] D 273, S.

“As soon as the tathāgata, arhat, perfect and complete buddha King of Jewels—the brilliant light of whose good qualities is as beautiful as a glorious pure sky free from dust; whose body is like a lotus flower, lovely as a resplendent blue beryl gemstone; who is worshipped with the most supreme and excellent perfumes; whose body is elegantly adorned in manifold ways; who radiates immeasurable sunrays from the top of his beautiful crown ornament; who is ornamented with an aspiration like radiant moonbeams; who is a supreme emanation, devoid of desire, with a vast array that manifests out of the expanse of phenomena—passes into parinirvāṇa and his teachings fade away, the bodhisattva Incomparable will attain unsurpassed, perfect, completely manifest awakening. He will appear in that world and be known as Victory Banner King—a learned and venerable tathāgata, arhat, perfect and complete buddha; a sugata, a knower of the world, an unsurpassed guide who tames beings, teacher of gods and humans; a blessed buddha whose space-like body resembles the youthful Varuṇa, chu lha gzhon nu] D 273, D 511, D 853; chu zla gzhon nu] S. the light of the sun, a moon flower, zla ba’i me tog] D 511, D 853; zla ba’i me tog rin chen] D 273. This translation follows D 511 and D 853. The variant in D 273 might translate as “a moon flower or gem” or perhaps “a precious moon flower.” and a beautiful golden lotus; one who is adorned with rays of sunlight, an unimpeded halo radiating beams of light throughout the ten-directional circular maṇḍala and illuminating the entire world.

“The tathāgata, arhat, perfect and complete buddha of the eastern quarter called Stainless Light of the Entire Array bkod pa thams cad dri med ’od] D; bkod pa dri med ’od] S; bgrod pa thams cad dri med ’od] J, K, N, KY. will behold him, issue an utterance, and prostrate. The tathāgata, arhat, perfect complete buddha of the southern quarter named Thought Adorned with Eloquence spobs pa’i rgyan la dgongs pa] D; spobs pa’i rgyal la dgongs pa] S. will behold him and direct his attention toward him. yid la bya] D 273, D 511, D 853, S. The phrase “direct his attention toward him” (yid la bya, manaskāryaḥ) is suspect, and breaks with the pattern that is repeated for all the other tathāgatas in this sequence. I believe that the Tibetan preserves a scribal error in the Sanskrit here that read some form of manas + kṛ (yid la bya) instead of the namas + kṛ (phyag bya’o) that appears in all other phrasings of the sequence of the twelve buddhas in this text. Nevertheless, I have translated this instance as yid la bya to accurately reflect the Tibetan. The tathāgata of the western quarter named Renowned Victor Crowned with a Clear Moon will behold him and prostrate. The tathāgata of the northern quarter Manifesting an Array of Flowers will behold him and prostrate. The tathāgata of the southeastern quarter named Light Maker will behold him and prostrate. The tathāgata of the southwestern quarter named Renowned Supreme Jewel Crown will behold him and prostrate. The tathāgata of the northwestern quarter named Fearless and All-Seeing will behold him and prostrate. The tathāgata of the northeast quarter named Bristling with Fearless Confidence ’jigs bral bag tsha ba mi mnga’ spu zing mi byed] D 273; ’jig bral bag tsha mi mnga’ spu zing mi byed] D 511, D 853. will behold him and prostrate. The tathāgata of the nadir named Throat of the Yawning Lion will behold him and prostrate. The tathāgata of the zenith named Fearless King Majestic Golden Radiance will behold him and prostrate.

“Maitreya, sons or daughters of the lineage with sincere faith should recite the names of these twelve tathāgata, arhat, perfect complete buddhas and over the course of ten days as they confess all their misdeeds, rejoice in all foundations of virtue, request that all the buddhas turn the wheel of Dharma, request that all the buddhas remain in the world, and dedicate all these roots of virtue to the expanse of phenomena.

“All their misdeeds will be exhausted and all their karmic obscurations will be purified. After that, they will obtain the excellent conditions of a buddhafield with a vast array of good qualities, fearlessness, the marks of an awakened being, a saṅgha of bodhisattvas, dhāraṇīs, and meditative concentration.

“Just as they have hoped, they will quickly attain the excellent conditions of a completely pure buddhafield and a spiritual teacher. Their realization of the state of unsurpassed complete perfect awakening will never diminish or disappear. As they take rebirth in cyclic existence, they will be good looking and wealthy, and they will attain the excellent conditions of being born into a successful family with a high social standing and good family traits. rigs phun sum tshogs pa dang / skye ba phun sun tshogs pa dang / rus phun sum tshogs pa dang ] D 273, D 511, D 853, S. The translation combines these three “excellent conditions” (phun sum tshogs pa) into a single clause that takes rigs (kula) to indicate the actual family line, skyes ba (jāti) to indicate that family line’s social standing, and rus (gotra) to indicate the inherited family traits. They will attain the excellent conditions of good health and having a great retinue of people around them of a similar lineage.
“Then they should recite the following verse:

lg.l: “From one lifetime to the next,
Wherever I take birth,
May I be handsome, attractive, radiant,
Powerful, and extremely rich.

div.p: “Then they should recite these root verses of the secret mantra dhāraṇī:

p.mantra: tadyathā akhe makhe samanta­mukhe sautiyukte nirukte prabhe sama­yoge cita­vivarte cita­vivarte] D 273; citta­citte] D 511, D 853; citta­cittarte] S. ame khame madane vivarte samanta­guṇe samanta­guṇe] D 273; samanta­guṇi] D 511, D 853. satyārame yukte prayukte hili mili masale ānale came aciṭi aciṭi aciṭi aciṭi] D 273; aciti] D 511, D 853. coce arahe bahudche bahudche] D 273; bahucche] D 511, D 853. māyugrahe hemavati jyotivati dharmaciti dharmaciti] D 273; dharmacite] D 511; dharmacitte] D 853. cyutapaṅke cyutapaṅke] D 511, D 853; cyuta­vaṅgke] D 273. avikṣepe radhikṣa radhikṣa] D 273, radhṛkṣa] D 511, D 853. me skandha­vibhakte
p.note:
Tentative English translation:
tadyathā akhe makhe radiant one whose panoptic gaze is said to be fused with sunlight, whose thought is devoid of illusion, ame khame for whom intoxicating illusion fused and performed while delighting in truth is entirely virtuous hili mili masala ānale came aciṭi aciṭi coce worthy one bahudche golden one bathed in light who bears māyu, who knows the Dharma, who is without impurity, unwavering, and furnished with a great host—deliver this to me!

div.p: “Homage to all buddhas and bodhisattvas. With the blessing of the Buddha, may these root verses of the secret mantra be effective.”
The Buddha then explained this with the following verses:

lg.l: “The million sages
Who dwell in the ten directions
Will pay heed to those
Who bear these dhāraṇī verses in mind.
“In all their rebirths
They will encounter a spiritual teacher,
And whatever little virtue they possess
Will accomplish all their goals.
“Those who bear these dhāraṇī verses in mind
Will see the buddhas seated
In the center of lotuses before them
And be wise, fortunate, and take miraculous birth.
“Their recollection, intellect, understanding,
Devotion, and insight will increase.
They will understand all they have studied,
And their understanding of all they have studied will not diminish. thos pa thams cad ’dzin mi nyams] D 511, D 853; thos pa rnams ni yongs mi nyams] D 273.
“Those who recite the names
Of these world protectors
Will be free from all lower rebirths
And quickly proceed to the higher realms.
“They will realize
The supreme meditative concentrations and dhāraṇīs,
They will attain supreme awakening,
And they will purify millions of buddhafields.
“Those who give a gift that is full of gold
And bear the names
Of these tathāgatas in mind
Will have an exceedingly large heap of merit.
“They will always remember their past lives.
There will never be an inopportune moment
For them to practice the conduct of a bodhisattva,
And they will obtain the exquisite state of a buddha.
“They will serve the perfect buddhas.
They will obtain unsurpassed faith.
They will express their faith in the buddhas
And make supreme offerings to them.
“Honoring the state of the buddhas,
They shall see them and have faith in these teachers.
They will see these lamps that illuminate the world
And make excellent offerings to them.
“Those who bear these names in mind
Will be free from cyclic existence
For innumerable millions of eons
And quickly attain awakening.
“Those who bear these names in mind
For a total of seven days and nights
Will have a vision of all the guides of beings
And will perfect the power of panoramic sight.
“Those who bear the names
Of the world protectors in mind
Will be worthy of veneration
Wherever they might take rebirth.
“Those who bear these names in mind
Will not fall into disrepute
For unimaginable millions of eons,
But will be famous throughout all worlds.
“Those who bear these names in mind
Will be honored by the gods
For many eons
And quickly attain awakening.
“Those who bear these names in mind
Will not lack faith or lose insight,
Will give up distraction and deceit,
And will always see the buddhas.
“Those who bear these names in mind
Will always be protected
By gods, gandharvas, the nāga lords,
Garuḍas, asuras, and guhyakas.
“They will have excellent bodily forms and names
And will be born into opulent households.
They will be generous to all beings
And will be brave, magnanimous, and selfless.
“For many millions of eons,
They will always have the pleasant scent
Of divine red sandalwood,
And their breath will have the scent of perfume.
“Those who bear these names in mind
Shall speak with the eloquence of Brahmā
For millions of eons
And maintain the status of a Dharma king.
“Those who bear these names in mind
Will have divine bodies,
And great riches will spring from the many-million petals
Of the lotus of the seven royal treasures.
“Those who bear these names in mind
Will never find themselves
Without fathers, mothers, siblings, loved ones,
And a multitude of good people.
“If a woman has borne the names
Of these great sages in mind,
She will be freed from her feminine form
And become an intelligent man.
“After attaining the next human rebirth,
She will attain unsurpassed awakening,
Turn the wheel of the Dharma,

And easily attain nirvāṇa. ’dod pa ji bzhin mya ngan ’da’] D 273, D 511; ’dod pa zhi bzhin mya ngan ’da’] D 853. This translation follows the reading in D 273 and D 511. The Negi dictionary (p. 2620.1) notes that ’dod pa ji bzhin is a translation of the Sanskrit abhipriya, and Edgerton (p. 54.2) provides an example where the term is used as an adjective meaning “quite agreeable.” This translation opts instead to read ’dod pa ji bzhin as a Tibetan translation of the Sanskrit yathākāma. The variant in D 853 translates “pacify all desire, and attain nirvāṇa,” which does not make sense given the fact that the subject of the verse has already attained awakening.
“Those who bear these names in mind
Cannot be harmed
By weapons, poison,
Fire, kings, or criminals.
“The thoughts of those
Who bear these names in mind
Will never be troubled
By Māra, mounted on his chariot with his retinue.
“A human being who bears
The names of these buddhas in mind
Can course through space
Across infinite millions of buddhafields.
“After making offerings to the buddhas who teach there,
They must petition them for protection.
The victors will understand their wishes
And issue prophecies of their awakenings.
“After they receive prophecies
From those buddha lords,
They will be exceedingly joyful
And have no doubt in the Victor’s teaching.
“Those who bear these names in mind
Will hear the profound Dharma
From all the world protectors
And retain all they have heard.
“Then they will perfect
All the perfections and the grounds,
The four types of fearlessness, the powers,
And the major and minor marks.
“Their wish will be fulfilled
In the field of one of those buddhas.
They will realize unsurpassed, perfect,
Complete awakening and become a buddha.
“A buddha could describe
These and the other qualities
Of any man or woman
Who bears these names in mind for an entire eon.
“People who heed this teaching
And learn about these excellent qualities
Should bear the names of these renowned
Perfect buddhas in mind.
“Anyone who hears the names
Of these buddhas who are glorious by nature,
Who are world protectors, supreme among human beings,
And celestial kings in the course of an eon and
“Those who hear and learn their names
Will be moved by devotion,
Will develop great insight into all things,
And will become supreme among human beings.
“What wise, insightful person,
Having learned the names of these great sages
And heeded this teaching,
Would not bear them in mind?”

div.p: After the Blessed One said this, the bodhisattva great being Maitreya, the entire retinue of monks and bodhisattvas, and the whole world with its gods, humans, asuras, and gandharvas was delighted and praised his words.
div.trailer: This concludes the noble Mahāyāna sūtra “The Twelve Buddhas.”

div.head: Colophon
div.p:
This text was translated and edited by the Indian teachers Jinamitra and Dānaśīla along with the chief editor and translator Bandé Yeshé Dé and then finalized. The colophon to D 273 ends here, with no mention of the text being revised.
It was later revised according to the new language reform and then finalized.

Southern continent of the human world according to traditional Indian cosmology, characterized as the “Rose Apple.”

The ancient capital of Magadha prior to its relocation to Pataliputra during the Mauryan dynasty, Rājagṛha is one of the most important cities and geographic locations in Buddhist literature. The literature tells us that the Buddha and his saṅgha spent a considerable amount of time in residence in and around Rājagṛha enjoying the patronage of King Bimbisāra and then his son King Ajātaśatru of Magadha. Rājagṛha is also remembered as the location where the first Buddhist monastic council was held after the Buddha Śākyamuni passed into parinirvāṇa.
